abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Highway Project in Madagascar
            was achieved. The working relationship between the
            International Development Association (IDA) and the borrower
            was generally good. Generally the project has been
            successfully implemented although disbursements were much
            slower than anticipated. The dialogue with the Association
            on the whole has also been good throughout the project.
            Although the project was justified, a major shortcoming was
            the delay in implementing effective highway maintenance. In
            the past this was the result of slow procurement of
            maintenance In the past this was the result of slow
            procurement of maintenance equipment. Another important
            reason, was very limited Government funds, in turn due to
            stringent economic conditions and institutional capability.
            Much of this was not foreseeable at the time of appraisal.
            Some of the loss of key staff was evident already then, but
            became worse. In general the Association over estimated the
            capacity of the Ministry of Public Works (MPW) to undertake
            the project and some earlier technical assistance and
            solutions like the use of procurement agents may have
            helped. The lesson learned in this project nevertheless have
            facilitated implementing the succeeding projects.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project consists of: (a)
            reconstruction of 67 km two-lane paved road between
            Arivonimamo and Analavory (RNI); (b) construction to gravel
            standards of a 370 km secondary road between Tsiroanomandidy
            and Maintirano; (c) provision of consulting services for
            engineering and supervision of construction of the
            Tsiroanomandidy-Maintirano road; (d) purchase of maintenance
            equipment, spare parts, weigh bridges, portable scales and
            vehicles, following a study to determine requirements; and
            (e) training of the staff of the Ministry of Public Works,
            following a study to determine requirements.
